citation.article-title: Proposal of Sphingomonas suberifaciens (van Bruggen, Jochimsen and Brown 1990) comb. nov., sphingomonas natatoria (Sly 1985) comb. nov., Sphingomonas ursincola (Yurkov et al. 1997) comb. nov., and emendation of the genus Sphingomonas

p.s: Emendation of the genus Sphingomonas Yabuuchi, Yano, Oyaizu, Hashimoto, Ezaki and Yamamoto 1990

Gram-negative, asporogenous rods or ovoid cells. Soma size is 0.7 X 1.4 μm, 0.4 X 0.9 μm (S. suberifaciens), or 0.9 X 2.0 μm (S. ursincola). Budding or asymmetric division was visualized by electron microscopy in two species (S. natatoria and S. ursincola). Bipolar staining in Gram stain (S. ursincola) and rosett formation in some species, and single polar flagellum when motile. It is strictly aerobic. The metabolism is respiratory, never fermentative. The cells of one species (S. ursincola) contain bacteriochlorophyll a, and are facultative photoorganotroph. Colony color is different from species to species such as deep yellow, orange, brown-orange, faint yellow, creamy-yellow or non-pigmented. Catalase is produced. Oxidase positive with a few exceptions. The respiratory quinone is uniquinone 10. N-2'-hydroxymyristoyl dihydrosphingosine 1-glucuronic acid (SGL- 1) is the major sphingoglycolipid in the cellular lipids. Major long-chain bases are d-18:0, d-19:1, d-20:1, and d- 21:1. At present, the following 19 species are assigned in the genus Sphingomonas:
1. S. paucimobilis (Holmes et al 1977) Yabuuchi et al 1990
17. S. suberifaciens (van Bruggen et al 1990) Yabuuchi et al present study
18. S. natatoria (Sly 1985) Yabuuchi et al present study
19. S. ursincola (Yurkov et al 1997) Yabuuchi present study
Isolated from a wide variety of natural and artificial environments, some species are pathogenic for humans or vegetables.
G + C content of DNA ranges from 59 to 67% (HPLC).
Type species is Sphingomonas paucimobilis (Holmes et al 1977) Yabuuchi et al 1990.
